node.title: Structural analysis in moose
node.bodyText:
Hello All, I am new to MOOSE. I wanted to set up a simple structural analysis problem (deflection of a structure under pressure). I need some help in setting up the run. Highly appreciate if someone can help me start with MOOSE.
I would like to know if MOOSE is the right opensource code for structural analysis involving non linearities (material, geometry, contacts)? or do you suggest some other opensource codes
Naajein

Hello
You may want to check out our learning resources for MOOSE
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html
then please check out the documentation and tutorials from the tensor mechanics module
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/index.html
Guillaume

thank you for your response.  I would like to know if MOOSE is the right opensource code for structural analysis involving non linearities (material, geometry, contacts)? or do you suggest some other opensource codes
@hugary1995
@cbolisetti

Yes, MOOSE handles geometric and material nonlinearities. MOOSE is also capable of contact (kinematic, penalty, mortar), both frictional and frictionless. The resources @GiudGiud posted above are a good starting point.
thank you. I will go through the resource and connect if further questions.

while trying to install moose in windows 10, I get the following warning. Is it okay to go ahead and install in windows 10?
**Using MOOSE on Windows 10 is experimental and not fully supported.
Peacock does not work correctly (artifacts during rendering: surface normals are flipped).
Different flavors of Linux are available.

Be sure to choose an OS in which we support. While MOOSE will ultimately work on just about every flavor of Linux, this document assumes you have chosen Ubuntu 20.04.**

You may install on WSL on windows 10. You may NOT install on windows 10 directly, we do not support it
You can view output files to paraview installed either on windows or on WSL, so peacock (our GUI) is not really needed

Hello Guillaume

I was able to install MOOSE successfully.

I read that the mesh file should be in exodus format. How do I create an
exodus file. I am not sure how I open the peacock with the current set up.
Can you please help me

Regards
Naajein
…

N@@j!..:)

Peacock is in moose/python/peacock. You can run that to start peacock.
You may generate exodus file using Cubit, using the MOOSE meshgenerators, or converting from another format.
Exodus is not the only mesh format supported. see this page: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html

Hi there,
I had the same problem! I reinstalled ubuntu under wsl 2 again and it resolved my problems. Make sure that you install ubuntu 22.04.1 and not ubuntu. When launching VcXsrv, I did not toggle off native opengl.

node.title: how to set material "binding" with variable?
node.bodyText:
hello, i want to set a PDE like this $\bigtriangledown (v_{p} \times P) = \frac{\partial P}{\partial t} $, in this, $v_{p}$ is a Function about location. and the week form is
$<\varphi v_{p} P,\vec{n}> - (\bigtriangledown \varphi v_{p}P)-(\varphi, \frac{\partial P}{\partial t} )=0$ ,
but when i see the result， the moose solve as
$<\varphi v_{p} P,\vec{n}> - v_{p}(\bigtriangledown \varphi P)-(\varphi, \frac{\partial P}{\partial t} )=0$ .
my project is on my github. https://github.com/wangzhaohao/restruction/blob/main/src/kernels/ConservativePorosity.C
is there somthing i can do like comsol, in comsol, d(u+x, x) = ux+1, and pd(u+x, x) = 1. what can i do to tell moose $v_{p}$ is use inside. Do you have any suggestion? thanks for your reply.
Zhaohao Wang

Hello
So v_p is a MOOSE Function, it is a pre-determined potentially spatially-dependent and potentially time-dependent profile that you do not have to solve for?
Or do you mean you want v_p to be a nonlinear variable that the solver should solve for, same as pressure?
Guillaume
v_p is a known function. i dont need to  solve

and you want it to be inside the gradient?
I dont think we have an easy option to parse the gradient of that quantity for you, but you may write it explicitly in the kernel using the classic dab_dx = da_dx + db_dx
you mean is i take two part. and i see in heat conduction module the conductivity is set outside. there is we ignore divergence? why we dont need conside that.

If it s constant spatially we do not need to consider it.
@WilkAndy might know

Hello, GiudGiud. What if i want v_p to be a nonlinear variable that the solver should solve for, same as pressure? I just break it  into two parts right now. Is there any magic way to simplify the process.

I'm not exactly sure what is being asked here.  Is P a scalar variable, and v_p another scalar variable?  Is P a vector variable and v_p a vector-value function (is there a cross-product between v_p and P?)?   Or something else?   What is the difference between the two weak forms that you have written above?   And what does this mean: "d(u+x, x) = ux+1, and pd(u+x, x) = 1" ?    Sorry for my confusion - I can't help you without understand the question.

I'm not exactly sure what is being asked here.  Is P a scalar variable, and v_p another scalar variable?  Is P a vector variable and v_p a vector-value function (is there a cross-product between v_p and P?)?   Or something else?   What is the difference between the two weak forms that you have written above?   And what does this mean: "d(u+x, x) = ux+1, and pd(u+x, x) = 1" ?    Sorry for my confusion - I can't help you without understand the question.

on my question v_p is a function which is konwn about location, and p is a variable. they are all about x. v_p is not product by P. the different about two week form is whether v_p is a function. if is a function, i think the div is acting on v_p and P. if is not a function, div is not acting on v_p only on P.
my confusion point is how to set to let div acting   on v_p and P.

I'm not exactly sure what is being asked here.  Is P a scalar variable, and v_p another scalar variable?  Is P a vector variable and v_p a vector-value function (is there a cross-product between v_p and P?)?   Or something else?   What is the difference between the two weak forms that you have written above?   And what does this mean: "d(u+x, x) = ux+1, and pd(u+x, x) = 1" ?    Sorry for my confusion - I can't help you without understand the question.

on my question v_p is a function which is konwn about location, and p is a variable. they are all about x. v_p is not product by P. the different about two week form is whether v_p is a function. if is a function, i think the div is acting on v_p and P. if is not a function, div is not acting on v_p only on P. my confusion point is how to set to let div acting on v_p and P.

I'm beginning to understand.
Probably you're trying to solve the advection equation (the green equation in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advection ).   If that is true, then the weak form is encoded in the https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/TimeDerivative.html and https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ConservativeAdvection.html Kernels (along with any BCs that are appropriate for you).   You don't need to code any C++ to solve the advection equation using MOOSE: just use those two in-built Kernels.
If you've trying to solve du/dt + v.grad(u) = 0, where u is your Variable and v is a known vector field, then first note that this is not the advection equation.  I suggest writing this as du/dt + div(vu) - u div(v) = 0.  Then the first two terms are the advection equation, and are encoded as described in the last paragraph, while the final term can be described using https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/CoefReaction.html (but div(v) has to be a constant) or https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/MatReaction.html (you'd have to create a Material version of your Function)
Thanks，i got it

node.title: Point source on symmetric axis (RZ coord)
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I want to model a simple point acoustic source at the symmetric axis. Surely, I can make it in 3D with the point source in the middle but it would be much more efficient to move to an axial symmetric model with a point source at the z-axis. Unfortunately, whenever I try to place a point source at the z-axis the resulting acoustic waves are strange and incorrect. Is there an easy way around this?
Thanks!

@somu15
Could you please post a figure of the problem @lyyc199586  ?

sure,
in RZ coord:

I put a point source on the left side, which is the y-axis, and the acoustic wave becomes very noisy
The same setting in 2D planer gives:
HI @lyyc199586 Would it be possible to share your Moose input files for these two problems? Thanks.

This is my input file, to change to a standard coord system, just comment [Problem] block.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 3
  ymin = 1
  ymax = 4
  nx = 100
  ny = 100
[]

[Problem]
  coord_type = RZ
[]

[Variables]
  [./p]
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./vel_p]
  [../]
  [./accel_p]
  [../]
  [./accel_x]
  [../]
  [./accel_y]
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./inertia_p]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = 'p'
  [../]
  [./diff_p]
    type = ADMatDiffusion
    variable = 'p'
    diffusivity = 'Diff'
  [../]
[]

[DiracKernels]
  [point_source]
    type = FunctionDiracSource
    variable = p
    function = switch_off
    point = '0.0 1.75 0.0'
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [./switch_off]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'if(t < 0.1, 5e-4, 0)'
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '444.44'
  [../]
  [./diff]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'Diff'
    prop_values = '1000'
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [axial]
    type = DiffusionFluxBC
    variable = p
    boundary = left
  []
[]


[Postprocessors]
  [./p_1]
    type = PointValue
    variable = p
    # point = '0.5 1.01 0.0'
    point = '0 1.75 0'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      31                  preonly       lu           1'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  # automatic_scaling = true
  end_time = 2.1
  dt = 1.5e-3
  # end_time = 1
  # dt = 1e-3
  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  [./csv]
    type = CSV
    delimiter = ','
    file_base = 'pressure_hist'
  [../]
  [./exodus]
    type = Exodus
    interval = 100
    file_base = fluid
  [../]
[]

@lyyc199586  If you do not put the point source in the center (although for RZ, the point source will become a circular point source), does that solution look reasonable?  It looks like a numerical stability issue, and I am trying to think whether that could be due to the point source at the symmetric plane.
@somu15 might have some better suggestions for you to try.
If the point source is off-axis (in RZ), then it looks fine
I think its numerical error.  I changed nx to 1000 and made the timestep 1.5e-4 and the pressure output looks good.... I don't know if its right but it doesn't checkerboard
In real simulations a much finer mesh is used, but this problem still exist

There are two main issues here:

The dirac source isn't well defined along the symmetry axis when the coordinate system is rz. In cartesian coordinates the dirac kernel works in the following way: consider the integral \int_\Omega w s \delta(x-x0) dV, where \Omega is the entire domain, w is the test function, s is your point source, and \delta is the dirac delta function with the spike at x0. The integrand gets sifted out and you get w(x0) s(x0) JxW in the assembly process. The issue comes up when you do the coordinate transformation for rz, where the integral becomes \int_\Omega w s \delta(x-x0) 2 \pi r dV. Now, when this gets sifted out, it becomes zero because r = 0 along the symmetry axis. To get around this, you either need to use a crazily refined mesh (which can get rid of the noisy waves, but you are still relying on numerical integration error), or change the point source to a well defined volumetric source defined around the neighborhood of that point.
The ADMatDiffusion doesn't account for rz coordinates. The correct residual should be the following one. You can just use the ADCoefMatDiffusion we have in raccoon.

I tested this using the following input file, it works fine without further refinement:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 3
  ymin = 1
  ymax = 4
  nx = 100
  ny = 100
[]

[Problem]
  coord_type = RZ
[]

[Variables]
  [p]
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [inertia_p]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = p
  []
  [diff_p]
    type = ADCoefMatDiffusion
    variable = p
    prop_names = 'D'
  []
  [source_p]
    type = ADCoefMatSource
    variable = p
    prop_names = 's'
    coefficient = -1
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [s_func]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'r:=sqrt(x^2+(y-1.75)^2); if(t<0.1,if(r<0.25,5e-4,0),0)'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '444.44'
  []
  [diff]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'D'
    prop_values = '1000'
  []
  [source]
    type = ADGenericFunctionMaterial
    prop_names = 's'
    prop_values = 's_func'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  end_time = 2.1
  dt = 1.5e-3
  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]
Yes, actually ADCoefMatDiffusion is being used in real simulations, but this problem still exists.
The additional term accounting for the lapacian in cylindrical coordinates won't remove the checkerboarding. The volumetric source will.
Ok, I will try to use a volumetric source
Yeah, just make sure the source spans over a few elements. So you might need a little bit of local refinement around that point.

Then I just need to change this block to match the original dirac source, right?
[Functions]
  [s_func]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'r:=sqrt(x^2+(y-1.75)^2); if(t<0.1,if(r<0.25,5e-4,0),0)'
  []
[]
Right, you might need to do some calculations to make the total power input the same as before.

@hugary1995 Initially I thought about the change of lapacian operator in cylindrical coordinate, but we have never add that extra term for any diffusion kernels, including heat conduction. I sorted of convinced my self by looking at the weak form where only gradient term appears and the gradient term remains the same. After you brought this up, I think you are correct and we should start with governing equation and derive the weak form from there. Does that mean all our thermal calculation for RZ is not correct?
I don't know. I really hope someone proves me wrong on that.

@hugary1995 For your first point, I agree that the scalar factor r will zero out some contributions from the centerline nodes. However, we still get some nonzero value at two other nodes. Regardless of the accuracy issue, I am curious to know why that would trigger the oscillation in the solution.
So @hugary1995's method is the best alternative so far, but putting a dirac source on the Z-axis is still problematic. I'm just curious is there any way to implement dirac source in RZ
Hi, I may have a similar problem at hand. Can you help me?

What is your problem?
As @hugary1995 mentioned, the point source is not multiplied by the coordinate transformation factor. This means even with RZ, the point source is treated as a "point", not a "ring".

−𝐊 (𝝏^𝟐 𝑼)/(𝝏𝒙^𝟐 )+𝑴 (𝝏^𝟐 𝑼)/(𝝏𝒕^𝟐 )= 𝜹(𝒙,𝒕), I want to solve this problem in infinite 1D domain. That is the left boundary and also the right boundary is infinite. And the Dirac force is implemented on the mid-point. I am confused about how will input the boundary condition.
If you have any ideas tell me.

node.title: Best practices for solving Phase-Field equations for a multiphase system
node.bodyText:
I have few questions regarding the use of phase field module available in moose:

For solving multiphase problems (eta1, eta2,.....etan) which set of kernels and material property are most efficient?
The summation of etas equal to 1 should be explicitly be constrained or it should come implicitly from solving respective eta PDEs?
Can I use ACGrGrMulti instead of AllenCahn kernel for the bulk term in allen cahn equation for solving a multiphase grand potential problem with ACSwitching kernel instead of DerivativeMultiPhaseMaterial material property required earlier by AllenCahn?

Thanks
@dschwen @amjokisaari
Pinging @dschwen again...
And maybe @laagesen too

I would recommend either the KKS or the Grand Potential formulation. Both are explained in the manual and have examples in the test suite and docs. Side note, we really should write an action to set up both models!! We also have a sub lattice KKS model that we developed and published a year ago, for compound formalism free energies with multiple sublattices.
We have a Lagrange multiplier based enforcement. It is not the sum of etas that needs to be one, but the sum of the resulting switching functions, as those determine the phase fractions!
The acgrgr stuff is for poly crystal models with a hard coded polynomial free energy. It depends on what you need to model. We also have combined formulations with poly crystal and multi phase support.

node.title: How to reduce the memory required to run？
node.bodyText:
Hi！
My laptop's memory is 16G, and the program to run needs 17G.  I want to test it on the laptop first, and then run it on the server.  Is there any way to reduce the memory required to run？
Thanks in advance for your help!

Hello
If you are running in parallel, switch to serial to reduce memory.
You should remove any auxiliary variable that you dont really need as they cost memory.
If you can, the easiest solution is to run with a coarser mesh.
Another thing to improve is the preconditioning. What are you using right now?
Guillaume

Thanks！
The distribution of memory is as follows
  Finished Reading Mesh                                                       [  0.34 s] [  132 MB]
  Finished Setting Mesh                                                         [  0.61 s] [  244 MB]
  Setting Up Displaced Mesh
  Finished Preparing Mesh                                                    [  0.64 s] [  108 MB]
  Finished Setting Up Displaced Mesh                                  [  0.64 s] [  108 MB]
  Finished Initializing Equation Systems                                [  2.02 s] [  751 MB]
  Finished Initializing Displaced Equation System                 [  0.49 s] [  215 MB]
  Finished Initializing                                                              [  4.16 s] [  995 MB]
  Finished Setting Up                                                             [  6.33 s] [ 1511 MB]
  Finished Projecting Initial Solutions                                     [  6.18 s] [    0 MB]
  Finished Computing Initial Material Values                          [  8.42 s] [ 4204 MB]
  Finished Setting Up Materials                                              [  8.42 s] [ 4204 MB]
  Updating Geometric Search
  Updating Displaced GeometricSearch
  Finding Nearest Nodes                                                                [  6.81 s] [  277 MB]
  Finished Updating Displaced GeometricSearch                          [  6.81 s] [  277 MB]
  Finished Updating Geometric Search                                          [  6.81 s] [  277 MB]
  Reinitializing Because of Geometric Search Objects..                 [ 16.63 s] [  361 MB]

I have only two auxiliary variables coupled time.
My mesh has only 27w elems.
Precondition:
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO superlu_dist'
  line_search = none

And I wonder whether the simulation results and convergence ability are affected by not using preprocessing.
Thanks in advance for your help!

Preconditioning is usually necessary.
You can try some less-memory consuming forms, like Jacobi or block jacobi.
You can try to use non-full Jacobian preconditioning with PJFNK that will also consume less.
I see 4GB in materials. I imagine they are stateful materials because we save the initial value.
Are you outputting the material properties as well? That costs memory

Thanks!
I don't need to output the material properties,  and I wonder how to set it.
My [output] is only exodus = true.

to output material properties you add output = in the Materials block.
If all the other options dont work, I would reduce the mesh for this local computation
Thanks! I will try it.

Did you get this going?  Most-likely you were running out of memory due to using LU.  As @GiudGiud mentioned you might do better using asm or bjacobi.
Another thing to look into is running with distributed mesh: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/splitting.html
Thanks！I found that the excessive memory usage was caused by my unreasonable mesh, and it has been resolved now！

node.title: Tracking motion of mass particles suspended in a fluid
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team,
I have an array of mass particles suspended in a fluid. Their position is changing with every time step owing to the force field. The transient positions of those particles are stored in a vector format, something like the following:
$$
\begin{align}
\mathrm{X}[i, t] \\
\mathrm{Y}[i, t] \\
\mathrm{Z}[i, t] \\
\end{align}
$$
where $i$ is the index of the particle and $t$ stands for the timestep. Such a system with 4 particles can be seen in the screenshot below, where the 4 particles change their position with every timestep. The transient positions of these particles will be stored as explained above, $\mathrm{X}[{i =1..4}, t={1..3} ], \mathrm{Y}[{i =1..4}, t={1..3} ], \mathrm{Z}[{i =1..4}, t={1..3} ]$

I need your kind help in visualising the trajectory of these particles as shown in the following screenshot. Could you please help me by suggesting a tool or method to visualise these transient trajectories in MOOSE?

Hello
And you are using the ray tracing module to do that?
Have you tried these outputs if you are:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/outputs/RayTracingExodus.html ?
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you for your response. Actually, RayTracingExodus was my preferred choice to output the trajectories.
But as I have been advised by you and Derek, I need to write a RayKernel for changing the ray trajectory in discussion #21283, I am unable to figure out how to implement that.
I was wondering if you could help me or guide me on how to change the trajectory using a RayKernel.
I checked this resource for RayKernels (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/RayKernels/index.html).
const Point some_point(1, 2, 3); // must be within _current_elem!
const Point some_direction(1, 0, 0);
changeRayStartDirection(some_point, some_direction);

I am puzzled as to how this can be implemented for my current scheme where the transient positions are stored in form of arrays.
I would appreciate your help on this. Thank you.

You would have to treat the particles one by one, the ray kernels act on a single ray not multiple.
These 3 lines would be fine to initialize the trajectory of one particle.
@oanaoana this made me think of you
any update on this?
Pinging again to see if you have an update on this.

node.title: How to couple 2D heat conduction equations with 1D fluid conservation equations?
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone!
I have developed a single-phase flow application based on three conservation equations. And I want to couple solid heat conduction equations with it to achieve conjugate heat transfer.
As the flow model is 1D, for each node of the channel in, like z direction, there should be a solid heat conduction equation to transfer heat in the x direction.
So this is a problem of coupling a 2D heat conduction equation and 1D fluid conservation equations, as I should use the temperature of the boundary of the heat structure to calculate heat transfer from solid to fluid.
How can I achieve it? THX!

Hello
You will want to use heat structures for now, see the tutorial
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/site/modules/thermal_hydraulics/tutorials/single_phase_flow/step02.html#step-2-conjugate-heat-transfer
In a few months we ll be able to run other modules (such a multi-D heat conduction using the heat conduction module) in combination with THM, we ll keep you posted.
Guillaume

You can put something together yourself pretty easily.
Use GapValueAux in each direction to get the temperature on the other side of the gap in each direction... then simply apply CoupledConvectiveHeatFlux on both sides.
Now - this won't be perfectly conservative... but with a reasonable mesh it will work well enough (it's what we used for many years before we got the more sophisticated schemes in GapHeatTransfer

node.title: Interface setting on CUBIT mesh
node.bodyText:
All,
I have a mesh generated by CUBIT (please see the attached sketch).
I would like to add interfaces on the left, right, top, and bottom sides of Block 2.
All I know is to use "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" which generates one interface around Block 2.
CUBIT generated SideSets for these left, right, top and bottom boundaries.
Please help me to generate separately the interfaces on the left, right, top, and bottom sides of Block 2.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas
Interfaces_two_variables_two_blocks.pdf

Hello
You may use the SidesetsAroundSubdomainGenerator with a normal parameter since the sidesets are all with a different normal.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator.html
You will need to use as many of these objects, chained using the input parameter, as there are sidesets to add.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I am using "InterfaceDiffusion" of "InterfaceKernels" whose interface is generated by "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" (test/tests/interfacekernels/hybrid/interface.i).
"SidesetsAroundSubdomainGenerator" seems to generate the same interface as "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" does.
Please confirm that is true.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas
you ll have to use the normal parameter to distinguish each surface

Thank you, Guillaume.
Both "SidesetsAroundSubdomainGenerator" and "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" produce the same results for the interface model.
S. Thomas

node.title: Error after updating Moose
node.bodyText:
Hello:
Due to a "missing symbol" problem with my app, I decided to eliminate some possibilities and so updated my Moose environment and Moose itself using the instructions from Getting Started.  Namely:
conda activate moose
conda update --all

cd ~/projects/moose
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/master

Then, I tried to run the tests.  I got more than 50 failures, and so ran

git clean -xfd

Upon trying to run the tests, I then got this error:

(moose) moose % cd test 
(moose) test % ./run_tests -j12
Building and linking hit...
make[1]: Entering directory '/Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit'
Building hit for python with python3-config
mpicxx -std=c++17 -g -march=core2 -mtune=haswell -mssse3 -ftree-vectorize -fPIC -fPIE -fstack-protector-strong -O2 -pipe -stdlib=libc++ -fvisibility-inlines-hidden -fmessage-length=0 -isystem /Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include -std=c++17 main.cc parse.cc lex.cc braceexpr.cc -o hit
make[1]: Leaving directory '/Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit'
Error! Could not find libmesh_config.h in any of the usual locations!

This is on an intel Mac, running 12.6.1.
Help please!  Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
I'd be worried that git clean -xfd removed the moose install. Did you remake moose after updating libmesh?
The missing libmesh_config.h is pointing to a missing libmesh but that could be a red herring.
I would also check the version of libmesh with
 mamba list | grep moose
then I would rebuild moose in moose/test
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume:
After running 'git clean -xfd' (as suggested in another discussion), I then went to /test and entered ./run_tests.  So I did not explicitly enter the make command.
Also:
(moose) test % mamba list | grep moose
# packages in environment at /Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose:
moose-libmesh             2022.10.05              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.1.0               he71d177_12    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.2                   build_2    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.16.6                  build_1    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2022.07.18      py310hcffbc79_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
Thanks for the help,
Joe

The moose-libmesh and moose-tools are a little on the older side. I have:
moose-libmesh             2022.11.07              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.1.0               h829a923_14    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.2                   build_4    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.16.6                  build_3    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2022.11.07      py310ha2ead4d_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public

it could be that the update is failing, in which case you will need to rmeove the mamba environment and try again
For now, can you please try to make in moose/test and try the tests again

Thanks Guillaume.  That fixed the problem with not being able to run the Moose tests.
I then went back and ran 'mamba update --all' and now have:
moose-libmesh             2022.11.07              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.1.0               hf2274b2_14    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.2                   build_4    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.16.6                  build_3    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2022.11.07      py310hcffbc79_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
So, should I rerun 'git clean -xfd' in my moose directory now that I have successfully updated the environment?
Joe
not every time really, only when you run into compilation issues.

So, now back to my original problem.  Just let me know if this should be a new issue.
In my app, I used 'git clean -xfd' and rebuilt.  I still get the dreaded "dyld[75408]: missing symbol called" when I try to run a test problem.
Is there any way to find what symbol?
Thanks,
Joe

is this all you get?
Is this in opt mode or debug mode?
Since you git cleaned the rational explanation for that is now that there s a missing implementation in a class

It was in opt mode.  And sadly, that is all I get.  I ran in dbg mode earlier and didn't see anything useful either.
I'll go back and check every class for a missing function.  Likewise, I did an 'otool -L' and saw nothing meaningful.  Should I try it with dbg again?
Thanks for the help,
Joe

@lindsayad thoughts about this?
Can you please paste the otool -L output?
@milljm

It looks like moose exists up one directory from your application. I see that git clean -xfd was run in previous posts. But I am not sure where it was performed. That said, when obtaining new versions of moose-libmesh (which means anything downstream of that; moose-petsc, moose-mpich), it is necessary to clean your build, rebuild, and then you can test. For you that means:
cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
cd ~/projects/ASP
git clean -xfd
make
Of course, be careful using git clean -xfd. This will delete any uncommitted, non-tracked files.
That said, did you perform a git clean in both the moose directory and your application directory? The links you provide all look good. But then again, the files won't change names, but the symbols in those file might (moose-libmesh's @rpath/../libmesh/lib/libmesh_opt.0.dylib library will have been updated if moose-libmesh was updated.)

I will redo my "cleaning" just to make sure it was done in the right order.
I tried doing a non_unity build just in case that might turn up something.  Ironically, the error it found was in the framework:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/src/postprocessors/CumulativeValuePostprocessor.C:10:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/CumulativeValuePostprocessor.h:12:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/GeneralPostprocessor.h:13:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/Postprocessor.h:12:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/OutputInterface.h:13:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseTypes.h:13:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/ADReal.h:13:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DualRealOps.h:16:
In file included from /Users/joe/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/SparseOps.h:13:
In file included from /Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/metaphysicl/dualsemidynamicsparsenumberarray.h:31:
In file included from /Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/metaphysicl/dualsemidynamicsparsenumberarray_decl.h:27:
/Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/metaphysicl/dualnumber_decl.h:35:10: fatal error: 'metaphysicl/ct_types.h' file not found
#include "metaphysicl/ct_types.h"
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Is that anything I should worry about?
Thanks.

Any order works, so if you performed a git clean in both, at any time after a mamba update --all should suffice. However:
This actually looks like what you have installed via Conda, is out-of-sync with what version of moose you have cloned (this version of moose might need an older version of moose-libmesh).
I suppose our instructions should say something like:

If you update moose then

you should also update Conda (mamba update --all)


If you update Conda then

you should also update moose (git fetch; git pull)
Did the cleaning in the order suggested, just to make sure.  Rebuilt and same problem with 'missing symbol called'.

I see you've done a fetch/rebase... You should have the latest available everything then... what is your origin?
cd ~/projects/moose
git remote -v

Here it is:
(moose) moose % git remote -v
origin	https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git (fetch)
origin	https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git (push)
Just rebuilt Moose & reran all tests.  No failures.

I am not seeing an issue in how/what you've done thus far:
cd ~/projects/moose
git rebase origin/master
mamba activate moose
mamba update --all
git clean -xfd
cd ../ASP
git clean -xfd
make
This appears to have been done throughout the course of this thread. But the error:
In file included from /Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/metaphysicl/dualsemidynamicsparsenumberarray_decl.h:27:
/Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/metaphysicl/dualnumber_decl.h:35:10: fatal error: 'metaphysicl/ct_types.h' file not found
#include "metaphysicl/ct_types.h"
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

does indicate something out of sync. Either the version of moose at ~/projects/moose, or what version of moose-libmesh is installed in your Conda environment (but you have the latest version, so... there is no disputing that).
You are also using the 'right' moose according to your otool -L asp-opt readout. I am a bit stumped at the moment...
@joe61vette, if possible, can you try to respond within a thread? It's a little more difficult to follow when the discussion is carried across Answers. What is the output of echo $LIBMESH_DIR?
I'm also curious what the undefined symbol was

Here you go:
ASP % echo $LIBMESH_DIR
/Users/joe/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh
The major problem is that I don't know what symbol is missing.  Here is the error message:
(moose) Tests % asp 1d-gravity.i
dyld[2210]: missing symbol called
zsh: abort      /Users/joe/projects/ASP/asp-opt -i 1d-gravity.i
Earlier I tried a dbg version but no info as to the missing symbol there either.
Tomorrow, I will systematically remove routines from my app until I find the one that causes the dyld problem.  I can't think of anything else.

Good Morning All:  I removed all of the header and source files from my app except those generated automatically when you run stork.sh.  Recompiled and the simple_diffusion.i test problem ran.  So, I'll begin adding back my routines to find the culprit.
Thanks again for the help,
Joe

It appears that I was missing a small utility function.  Something that got missed when switching branches. Thanks everyone for the help.  At least I did need it to get my Moose environment straightened out.  I absolutely have to remember to use "mamba update --all" instead of "conda update --all" .

Sorry @joe61vette that sounds like a painful process. It's really obnoxious that your system didn't emit information about the missing symbol. My only suggestion in the future if you run into that same problem would be to try to get access to a Linux system because they list undefined symbols in detail (albeit mangled, but it can be demangled easily using web tools like demangler.com) at link time. Mac lazily checks for undefined symbols during run-time and apparently sometimes doesn't give detailed info about what's missing.
I'm very glad you were able to get it worked out though!

node.title: How does the IntegratedBC work?
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I find that the return value of NeumanBC is negative in NeumannBC.C. Could anyone kindly explain it to me? Why it is negative?
Best regards,
SomnusYu
You can read some basics of finite element method, e.g., weak form, etc. After applying integration by parts and divergence theory, there will be a negative sign for the Neumann boundary conditions.
Thank you!

It's due to the fact that we always write a Poisson/Laplacian/Diffusion problem with a negative on the divergence term.  This is a convention because when you integrate by parts to form the weak form you end up with a symmetric positive definite (SPD) matrix.
You can see the whole process here... including the integration by parts that generates the boundary integral (which still has a negative on it).
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial01_app_development/step04_weak_form.html#step-4-generate-a-weak-form
OK, thank you very much!
